awd_titl_txt: ARI-R2: Integrated Science Research Experimental Laboratory
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (Public Law 111-5).    

This award funds the redesign, renovation, and upgrade of the ground floor of the Science Building complex on the campus of Calvin College to create the Integrated Science Research Experimental Laboratory  (ISRx).   The ISRx will place student and faculty researchers from a variety of disciplines in the same physical environment. The science that emerges from research performed in this space is expected to be highly interdisciplinary. Of particular note will be collaborations between chemistry/biology and computer science/mathematics researchers.   The affected chemistry research areas include genomics, proteomics, biofuels, biomolecule binding, structure, and imaging.  

The renovations will improve conditions for research training of students, and will promote interdisciplinary research by providing a common research area.  Calvin provides a variety of science outreach activities to the Grand Rapids area, focusing primarily on sections of Grand Rapids that have significant ethnic minority populations, and these activities will be enhanced by the proposed renovations.

por.por_cntn:
Funding from this award has made possible the construction of an interdisciplinary laboratory serving faculty and undergraduate researchers from the Biology, Biochemistry, Chemistry, Computer Science, and Physics departments at Calvin College. This past summer the laboratory housed 16 summer undergraduate researchers advised by 8 Calvin faculty. In addition, the lab housed 3 high school student researchers, with support from the American Chemical Society (Project SEED) and Howard Hughes Medical Institute. The research projects are expected to yield 5 submitted manuscripts over the following academic year. Three of the four senior undergraduate researchers will be applying to graduate research programs, where all are expected to be admitted. 

 

The collaborative environment has allowed for interdisciplinary research to expand and deepen, reflecting a key emphasis in 21st century science. The Nelesen (Computer Science) and Wertz (Biology) groups have written an algorithm that uses masses of proteins in bacterial lysates to rapidly identify bacterial species without the need for time-intensive DNA amplification methods (e.g. polymerase chain reaction). The Benson (Biochemistry) and Nelesen (Computer Science) groups have developed an algorithm that identifies crosslinks between protein side chains from mass spectrometry data. The Benson (Biochemistry) and Tatko (Chemistry) groups have developed methods to monitor all species consumed and produced as the enzyme cysteine dioxygenase produces its product. The Benson (Biochemistry) and Wertz (Biology) groups have been working on identifying the function of a a new protein (BF4112) from a bacterium (Bacteroides fragilis) that resides in the guts of animals. Overall, a variety of collaborative projects have been flourished in the the interdisciplinary research space, and undergraduate students have learned what it means to work effectively in an interdisciplinary environment, a critical step as real-world issues (e.g.,food, energy, health, environment) grow increasing complex and problem-solving requires contributions from multiple disciplines.

Modified by: David E Benson
